title: 106_hr3993
content: The Act titled "Prompt Payment of Health Benefit Claims Act of 2000" establishes standards for prompt payment of health benefit claims by group health plans and health insurance issuers. The "Prompt Payment of Health Benefit Claims Act of 2000" requires group health plans and health insurance issuers to pay claims within specific timeframes and accept clean claims submitted according to set standards. Title I of ERISA 1974 is amended to include a new section. "Standard relating to prompt payment of claims is established in Section 714." "A group health plan and health insurance issuer must pay claims within 15 business days for electronic submissions or 30 days for written claims. Claims must meet standards set by the Social Security Act. Section 732(a) of the Act is amended to include additional sections." The table of contents in section 1 of the Act is amended by adding a new item after section 713, by striking "section 711" and inserting "sections 711 and 714". Sec. 714 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new standard relating to prompt payment of claims. A group health plan must pay claims within 15 business days for electronic submissions and 30 business days for written claims. Clean claims must adhere to standards set by the Social Security Act. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 4980D(d)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. Individual Health Insurance provisions are added to Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act after section 2752. SEC. 2753. STANDARD RELATING PATIENT FREEDOM OF CHOICE. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as they do in connection with a group health plan. Effective dates for group health plans start on or after January 1, 2001, while individual health insurance coverage starts on the same date. The collective bargaining exception states that for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act, the amendments made to the plan shall not apply until the last collective bargaining agreement terminates or January 1, 2001. Plan amendments solely to comply with the new requirements are not considered terminations. The Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services will coordinate to ensure regulations and enforcement policies related to the Act are administered consistently and efficiently to avoid duplication of efforts and prioritize enforcement. SEC. 3. Medicare+Choice organizations must promptly pay individuals enrolled through various lines of business. Effective date is for contract years starting on or after January 1, 2001.
